2 1 PROFESSOR BERNHARDI.â€œ Play in four aets, by Arthur Schnitzler (English Version bv Hetty Landstone) presented in a character reading of rhe Jewish Drama League at the Little Theatre, on Sunday. February 13. Chorus Bernard Benoliel Pointer Edgar Norfolk Sister Ludmilla May Haysac Dr. Oscar Bernhardi Walter Schoffeld Dr. Bernhardi. Leonard Calvert In presenting a character reading instead of a properly acted performÂ¬ ance, the Jewish Drama League is following the lead of the British Empire Shakespeare Societg'â€™s readÂ¬ ings at the Haymarkei Theatre. The Viennese plarwright. Arthur Schnitz Ierâ€™s play, Professor Bernhardi,â€œ which was first produced in Berlin in * 1912, has never before been scen in England although it is well known on the Continent. Miss Hetty LandÂ¬ stoneâ€™s translation strikes onc as being a good onc and the reading on SunÂ¬ day night whetted eneâ€™s appetite for a regular stage performishee. Professor Bernhardiâ€œ makes special appeal to a Jewish andience, for i1 deals with che bitter antiÂ¬ Semitic feelings in Central Europe. All che characters, except oue, ure men, and most of them are the doctors and professors in a clinie in Vienna. The elinic has been provided by Dr. Bernbardi, a Jew ofthe highest integrity. He is an idealist who labours solelz for his fellow men. The bitter opposition at thie start has been overcome by the execlienee of tho work done atthe elmicel institute, but owing to a humanitarian act. Dr. Bernbardi finds himselt up against the# clerical party. A Foung girl is dying, but she happily imagines that she will get hetter and is waiting for her lover to appear. The presencc of a priest would spoil her last illusion. and Dr. Bernhardi verv gentig reinses to allon the last rites to be adminisÂ¬ tered. For bis act he 1s sente to prison for 4wo months' for snerilege, and one is made to realise thet the sentence is brought abont ## politiÂ¬ cal imrigue. The priest, indeed, did bis best atthe trial to prevent the inÂ¬ Justice and oue of the finest things in che play is the beautifully written scene at the end in which the two ien, boch idealists serring their iden of right. pome to an understanding! and shake hands. The aclors read so well that aster the first few minntes oue hardly realised that thiev bad their books in #their hands. Every part was finely characterised. Mr. Frederie de Lara; expressed the fineness of the uncomÂ¬ promtising Professor Bernhardi and ho made oue feel the sterling goodness of thie man whose ouli fauit was that he was a Jew. As well tr#to sumnnarize the Dreyfus affair
in a paragraph as attempt a succinet. account
of this play. Bernhardi is a kind of Drevfus,
a Jewish doctor who. for strietle professional
renson, stamdls between a dying woman und
her briest. She believes, mistakenly, that she
has been cured, and Bernhardi will not let the
priest undeceive her. There follows a vigorous
exposure of the methods of the anti-Semitie
Clerieal party, which makes political capital
out of the ineident, and if we are not of that
parte we teel inelined to cheer the authon.
Al the last moment, however, he sudÂ¬
denlg betrags too eager partisans by pointing
out that a man less arrogant than Bernhard
micht have avoided all bis troubles. The hero
ol theaifair is dismissed as â€œ an arrogant ass.?
This linal twist turns the play into something
perilonsig like u joke anned at the BernÂ¬
Chardians, but what a dull joke! The piece,
already crammed with religions, political, and
Pethieal arguments, is further weighed down
with the administrative detail of a medical
institute; and most of the verbal confliets are
as hopeless dramatically as that in which a
loyal Jew and a loyal Catholie priest attempt
to reconeile their religions dilferences. Mr.
Soiner conveged something of the pig-headen
splemdlour of the truculent. Bernbardi, but ih
rest of the acting was on a lower plane.
